name: Stone tools
description: – 2.6 Mya: Stone tools - found in modern-day Kenya are older and only found on the archetype road. Ancient stone tools from Ethiopia (Oldowan) were hand-crafted by Australopithecus or related people.[further explanation needed]

name: control of fire
description: Earliest likely control of fire and cooking, by Homo habilis

name: Acheulean
description: Advanced (Acheulean) stone tools in Kenya by Homo erectus

name: origin of language
description: – 150 kya: Varying estimates for the origin of language

name: Bone tools
description: Bone tools in Africa by Homo erectus and/or Paranthropus boisei

name: Boats
description: – 40 kya: Boats

name: Hafting
description: Hafting in South Africa by Homo heidelbergensis

name: Woodworking
description: – 450 kya: Woodworking construction in Zambia by Homo heidelbergensis (The oldest known surviving buildings are made from stone and date back no more than 9,500 years.)

name: Food storage
description: – 200 kya: Food storage in the form of uncracked bones saved for their marrow in Qesem cave, Israel.

name: Hide and leather
description: Hide and leather clothing, footwear and shelter.

name: Pigments
description: Pigments in Zambia by Homo heidelbergensis

name: Schöningen
description: – 300 kya: Schöningen Spears in Germany likely by Homo heidelbergensis or early Neandarthals.

name: trade
description: The trade and long-distance (up to 50 miles) transportation of resources (e.g. obsidian), use of pigments, and possible making of projectile points in Kenya

name: Hafting
description: Hafting and early stone-tipped projectile weapons in Ethiopia

name: adhesive
description: Simple glue (adhesive) made of one kind of material, birch tar, in Central Italy by Neanderthals.

name: Beds
description: Beds in South Africa.

name: Clothing
description: – 90 kya: Clothing, among anatomically modern humans in Africa. Genetic evidence from body lice suggests a range of dates centering over 100 thousand years ago. The first bone scrapers appropriate for scraping hides to make supple leather were found in Morocco dating to 90–120,000 years ago.

name: Beads
description: – 100 kya: Beads in Israel and Algeria — implying string or thread

name: paints
description: Compound paints made in South Africa

name: burial
description: Funerals (in the form of burial) in Israel

name: Harpoons
description: Harpoons in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

name: Sibudu Cave
description: – 60 kya in Sibudu Cave in South Africa by Homo sapiens: Compound adhesives Arrows and other evidence of bow-and-arrow technology Sewing needle (implying thread of some kind)

name: Cave painting
description: – 62 kya: Cave painting in Spain by Neanderthal

name: Representational
description: .8–51.2 kya: Representational and Narrative art in Indonesia by Homo sapiens

name: Ground stone
description: – 30 kya: Ground stone tools – fragments of an axe in Australia date to 49–45 ka, more appear in Japan closer to 30 ka, and elsewhere closer to the Neolithic.

name: ochre
description: The oldest-known mines in the world are from Eswatini, and extracted hematite for the production of the red pigment ochre.

name: shoes
description: – 9 kya: Earliest evidence of shoes, suggested by changes in foot bone morphology in China by Tianyuan man. The earliest physical shoes found so far are bark sandals dated to 10 to 9 kya in Fort Rock Cave, United States. The oldest known leather shoe dated to 5.5 kya was found in excellent condition in the Areni-1 cave located in the Vayots Dzor province of Armenia.

name: Tally sticks
description: – 42 kya: Tally sticks (see Lebombo bone) in Eswatini

name: Flute
description: Flute in Germany

name: Mortar and pestle
description: Mortar and pestle in Southwest Asia

name: Rope
description: -28 kya: Rope and Cords for "hafting stone tools, weaving baskets, or sewing garments," according to Elis Kvavadze et al.

name: Amputation
description: Amputation and surgery. Medicine in a meaningful sense likely predates the human-chimpanzee split, as, for example, herbal medicine has been observed in other primates.

name: Ceramics
description: Ceramics (direct evidence) and weaving (impressions left in the ceramics) in Moravia (Czech Republic) and Georgia. (The oldest piece of woven cloth found so far was in Çatalhöyük, Turkey and dated to about 9,000 years ago.)

name: Oldest known ceramic sculpture
description: Oldest known ceramic sculpture

name: Domestication of the dog
description: Domestication of the dog in Siberia.

name: Bullroarer
description: – 17 kya Bullroarer

name: Fish hook
description: Fish hook in Okinawa Island, modern day Japan.

name: Star chart
description: – 3.7 kya: Star chart in France, and later Spain, Kashmir, Germany, and Egypt.

name: Pottery
description: – 16 kya: Pottery in China

name: Spear-thrower
description: Spear-thrower (atlatl), found in France.

name: Bread
description: Bread in Jordan

name: Spindle whorl
description: Spindle whorl, also the oldest wheel-like tool, at Nahal Ein Gev II (Israel)

name: Agriculture
description: ,000 BC – 9000 BC: Agriculture in the Fertile Crescent

name: Domestication of sheep
description: ,000 BC – 9000 BC: Domestication of sheep in Southwest Asia (followed shortly by pigs, goats and cattle)

name: Oldest known surviving building
description: – 9000 BC: Oldest known surviving building – Göbekli Tepe, in Turkey

name: Domestication of rice
description: – 6000 BC: Domestication of rice in China

name: Mudbricks
description: Mudbricks (unfired bricks), and clay mortar in Jericho.

name: well
description: Oldest known water well in Cyprus.

name: Pesse canoe
description: –7510 BC: The Pesse canoe is the oldest boat we have found, while early human habitation of Crete and Australia make clear human seafaring goes back tens or hundreds of thousands of years. (see above)

name: Proto-city
description: –7500 BC: Proto-city – large permanent settlements, such as Tell es-Sultan (Jericho) and Çatalhöyük, Turkey.

name: potatoes
description: –5000 BC: Domestication of potatoes, in southern Peru and northwestern Bolivia by pre-Columbian farmers, around Lake Titicaca.

name: Copper tools
description: –6500 BC: Copper tools, by the people of the Old Copper Complex from the Great Lakes region of North America.

name: Alcohol fermentation
description: Alcohol fermentation – specifically mead, in China

name: Sled dog
description: Sled dog and Dog sled, in Siberia.

name: lead smelting
description: Evidence of lead smelting in Çatalhöyük, Turkey

name: Kiln
description: Kiln in Mesopotamia (Iraq)

name: Irrigation
description: th millennium BC: Irrigation in Khuzistan, Iran

name: Proto-writing
description: – 3200 BC: Proto-writing in present-day Egypt, Iraq, Romania, China, India and Pakistan.

name: salt production
description: – 5600 BC: Oldest evidence of salt production found in Southeastern Europe, in the countries of Moldova and Romania.

name: cheese
location: Poland and on the Dalmatian coast of Croatia
description: – 5200 BC: Oldest evidence of cheese found, in Poland and on the Dalmatian coast of Croatia.

name: Sailing
description: Sailing - pottery depictions of sail boats, in Mesopotamia, and later ancient Egypt

name: Copper smelting
description: Copper smelting in Serbia.

name: Seawall
description: Seawall in Tel Hreiz, near Haifa, Israel.

name: Lacquer
description: th millennium BC: Lacquer in China

name: Cotton
description: Cotton thread, in Mehrgarh, Pakistan, connecting the copper beads of a bracelet.

name: Rowing oars
description: – 4500 BC: Rowing oars in China

name: Lost-wax casting
description: – 3500 BC: Lost-wax casting in Palestine or the Indus Valley

name: Fired bricks
description: Fired bricks in China.

name: roads
description: Paved roads, in and around the Mesopotamian city of Ur, Iraq.

name: Plumbing
description: Plumbing. The earliest pipes were made of clay, and are found at the Temple of Bel at Nippur in Babylonia.[b]

name: locks
description: Oldest evidence of locks, the earliest example discovered in the ruins of Nineveh, the capital of ancient Assyria.

name: wheels
description: – 3400 BC: Oldest evidence of wheels, found in the countries of Ukraine, Poland, and Germany.

name: sericulture
description: Silk garments (sericulture) in China

name: domestication of the horse
description: Probable first domestication of the horse in the Eurasian Steppes.

name: general anaesthesia
description: Wine as general anaesthesia in Sumer.

name: Seal (emblem)
description: Seal (emblem) invented around in the Near East, at the contemporary sites of Uruk in southern Mesopotamia and slightly later at Susa in south-western Iran during the Proto-Elamite period, and they follow the development of stamp seals in the Halaf culture or slightly earlier.

name: Ploughing
description: Ploughing, on a site in Bubeneč, Czech Republic. Evidence, c. 2800 BC, has also been found at Kalibangan, Indus Valley (modern-day India).

name: Tattoos
description: – 3100 BC: Tattoos in southern Europe

name: swords
description: The first documented swords. They have been found in Arslantepe, Turkey, are made from arsenical bronze, and are about 60 cm (24 in) long. Some of them are inlaid with silver.

name: City
description: City in Uruk, Sumer, Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq).

name: hats
description: One of the earliest documented hats was worn by a man (nicknamed Ötzi) whose body and hat found frozen in a mountain between Austria and Italy. He was found wearing a bearskin cap with a chin strap, made of several hides stitched together, resembling a Russian fur hat without the flaps.

name: Latrines
description: Dry Latrines in the city of Uruk, Iraq, with later dry squat Toilets, that added raised fired brick foot platforms, and pedestal toilets, all over clay pipe constructed drains.

name: Ljubljana Marshes Wheel
description: Earliest actual wheel ever found, the Ljubljana Marshes Wheel, made of wood, in Slovenia.

name: dice
description: Devices functionally equivalent to dice, in the form of flat two-sided throwsticks, are seen in the Egyptian game of Senet. Perhaps the oldest known dice, resembling modern ones, were excavated as part of a backgammon-like game set at the Burnt City, an archeological site in south-eastern Iran, estimated to be from between 2800 and 2500 BC. Later, terracotta dice were used at the Indus Valley site of Mohenjo-daro (modern-day Pakistan).

name: Tin
description: Tin extraction in Central Asia

name: Papyrus
description: – 2560 BC: Papyrus in Egypt

name: Reservoir
description: Reservoir in Girnar, Indus Valley.

name: Receipt
description: Receipt in Ancient Mesopotamia (Iraq)

name: Prosthesis
description: – 2800 BC: Prosthesis first documented in the Ancient Near East, in ancient Egypt and Iran, specifically for an eye prosthetics, the eye found in Iran was likely made of bitumen paste that was covered with a thin layer of gold.

name: Rhinoplasty
description: – 2500 BC: Rhinoplasty in Egypt.

name: Ruler
description: The Ruler, or Measuring rod, in the subdivided Nippur, copper rod, of the Sumerian Civilisation (modern-day Iraq).[c]

name: Planned city
description: Planned city in Indus Valley.

name: Public sewage and sanitation systems in Indus Valley
description: Public sewage and sanitation systems in Indus Valley sites such as Mohenjo-daro and Rakhigarhi.

name: Public bath
description: Public bath in Mohenjo-daro, Indus Valley (modern-day Pakistan).

name: Levee
description: Levee in Indus Valley.

name: Balance weights and scales
description: Balance weights and scales, from the Fourth Dynasty of Egypt; examples of Deben (unit) balance weights, from reign of Sneferu (c. 2600 BC) have been attributed.

name: Docks
description: Docks structure in Wadi al-Jarf, Egypt, which was developed by the reign of the Pharaoh Khufu.[d]

name: Puppetry
description: Puppetry in the Indus Valley.

name: Fork
location: Bronze Age Qijia culture in China
description: Fork in Bronze Age Qijia culture in China

name: Copper pipes
description: Copper pipes, the Pyramid of Sahure, an adjoining temple complex at Abusir, was discovered to have a network of copper drainage pipes.

name: Touchstone
description: Touchstone in the Indus Valley site of Banawali (modern-day India).

name: Dictionary
description: Dictionary in Mesopotamia.

name: Iron smelting
description: – 2000 BC: Iron smelting in Kaman-Kalehöyük.

name: Protractor
description: Protractor, Phase IV, Lothal, Indus Valley (modern-day India), a Xancus shell cylinder with sawn grooves, at right angles, in its top and bottom surfaces, has been proposed as an angle marking tool.

name: Water clock
description: Water clock by at least the old Babylonian period (c. 2000 – c. 1600 BC), but possibly earlier from Mohenjo-Daro in the Indus Valley.

name: Chariot
description: Chariot in Russia and Kazakhstan

name: Scissors
description: Scissors, in Mesopotamia.

name: Proto-Sinaitic script
description: Proto-alphabet (Proto-Sinaitic script) in Egypt.

name: Surgical treatise
description: Surgical treatise appeared in Egypt.

name: Sundial
description: Sundial in Ancient Egypt or Babylonia (modern-day Iraq).

name: Glass
description: Glass manufacture in either Mesopotamia or Ancient Egypt.

name: Seed drill
description: Seed drill in Babylonia.

name: Rubber
description: Rubber, Mesoamerican ballgame.

name: Concrete
description: – 1200 BC: Concrete in Tiryns (Mycenaean Greece),

name: Lathe
description: Lathe in Ancient Egypt.

name: Distillation
description: Distillation is described on Akkadian tablets documenting perfumery operations.

name: Star catalogue
description: Star catalogue — Three Stars Each is the earliest known catalogue in long-running tradition of Babylonian astronomy, likely drawing on Sumerian and/or Elamite constellations.

name: Saddle
description: Saddle (fringed cloths or pads used by Assyrian cavalry).

name: Library of Ashurbanipal
description: th century BC: The royal Library of Ashurbanipal at Nineveh had 30,000 clay tablets, in several languages, organized according to shape and separated by content. The first recorded example of a library catalog.

name: Crossbow
description: Crossbow in China.

name: Coins
description: Coins in Phoenicia (Modern Lebanon) or Lydia.

name: High Carbon Steel
description: th century BC – 10th century AD: High Carbon Steel, produced by the Closed Crucible method, later known as Wootz steel, of South India.[f]

name: Sushruta Samhita
description: th century – 2nd century BC: Systematization of medicine and surgery in the Sushruta Samhita in Vedic Northern India. Documented procedures to: Perform cataract surgery (couching). Babylonian and Egyptian texts, a millennium before, depict and mention oculists, but not the procedure itself. Perform Caesarean section. Construct Prosthetic limbs. Perform Plastic surgery, though reconstructive nasal surgery is described in millennia older Egyptian papyri.

name: Lighthouse
description: Lighthouse in Greece.

name: Toe stirrup
description: – 200 BC: Toe stirrup, depicted in 2nd century Buddhist art, of the Sanchi and Bhaja Caves, of the Deccan Satavahana empire (modern-day India) although may have originated as early as 500 BC.

name: Catapult
description: Catapult by Ajatashatru in Magadha, India.

name: Ajatashatru
description: Scythed chariot by Ajatashatru in Magadha, India.

name: Cast iron
description: th century BC: Cast iron in Ancient China: Confirmed by archaeological evidence, the earliest cast iron is developed in China by the early 5th century BC during the Zhou dynasty (1122–256 BC), the oldest specimens found in a tomb of Luhe County in Jiangsu province.

name: Spiral stairs
description: Spiral stairs (Temple A) in Selinunte, Sicily (see also List of ancient spiral stairs)

name: zero
description: and 300 BC: Invention of the concept of zero in Babylon (now Iraq). It was invented independently by the Maya in the first few centuries A.D

name: Traction trebuchet
description: th century BC: Traction trebuchet in Ancient China.

name: Gears
description: th century BC: Gears in Ancient China

name: Reed pens
description: th century BC: Reed pens, utilising a split nib, were used to write with ink on Papyrus in Egypt.

name: Horseshoe
description: th century BC: Nailed Horseshoe, with 4 bronze shoes found in an Etruscan tomb.

name: Animal-driven rotary mill
description: – 350 BC: Animal-driven rotary mill in Carthage.

name: Zinc production
description: th to 3rd century BC: Zinc production in North-Western India during the Maurya Empire. The earliest known zinc mines and smelting sites are from Zawar, near Udaipur, in Rajasthan.

name: Analog computers
description: rd century BC: Analog computers in the Hellenistic world (see e.g. the Antikythera mechanism), possibly in Rhodes.

name: Cam
description: rd century BC: Cam during the Hellenistic period, used in water-driven automata.

name: Gimbal
description: rd century BC: Gimbal described by Philo of Byzantium

name: Blast furnace
description: rd century BC – 2nd century BC: Blast furnace in Ancient China: The earliest discovered blast furnaces in China date to the 3rd and 2nd centuries BC, although most sites are from the later Han dynasty.

name: Paper
description: nd century BC: Paper in Han dynasty China[g]

name: Compass
description: Compass in Han dynasty China

name: arch bridge
description: st century BC: Segmental arch bridge (e.g. Pont-Saint-Martin or Ponte San Lorenzo) in Italy, Roman Republic

name: newspaper
description: st century BC: News bulletin during the reign of Julius Caesar. A paper form, i.e. the earliest newspaper, later appeared during the late Han dynasty in the form of the Dibao.

name: Arch dam
description: st century BC: Arch dam (Glanum Dam) in Gallia Narbonensis, Roman Republic (see also List of Roman dams)

name: Glass blowing
description: – 14 BC: Glass blowing developed in Jerusalem.

name: Noodle
description: Noodle in Lajia in China

name: aeolipile
description: st century AD: The aeolipile, a simple steam turbine is recorded by Hero of Alexandria.

name: respiratory protective equipment
location: Roman mines from red lead oxide dust
description: st century AD: The first use of respiratory protective equipment is documented by Pliny the Elder (c. 23 AD–79) using animal bladder skins to protect workers in Roman mines from red lead oxide dust.

name: wine
description: st century AD: Oldest surviving wine.

name: Vending machines
description: st century AD: Vending machines invented by Hero of Alexandria

name: Seismometer
description: Seismometer and pendulum in Han dynasty China, built by Zhang Heng. It is a large metal urn-shaped instrument which employed either a suspended pendulum or inverted pendulum acting on inertia, like the ground tremors from earthquakes, to dislodge a metal ball by a lever trip device.

name: Carding
description: nd century: Carding in India.

name: Chaturanga
description: – 550: Chaturanga, a precursor of Chess was invented in India during the Gupta Empire.

name: Dichroic glass
description: th century: Roman Dichroic glass, which displays one of two different colors depending on lighting conditions.

name: Simple suspension bridge
description: th century: Simple suspension bridge, independently invented in Pre-Columbian South America, and the Hindu Kush range, of present-day Afghanistan and Pakistan. With Han dynasty travelers noting bridges being constructed from 3 or more vines or 3 ropes. Later bridges constructed utilizing cables of iron chains appeared in Tibet.

name: Fishing reel
description: th century: Fishing reel in Ancient China: In literary records, the earliest evidence of the fishing reel comes from a 4th-century AD work entitled Lives of Famous Immortals.

name: Oil Wells
description: Oil Wells and Borehole drilling in China. Such wells could reach depths of up to 240 m (790 ft).

name: Paddle wheel boat
description: th century – 5th century: Paddle wheel boat (in De rebus bellicis) in Roman Empire

name: Iron pillar of Delhi
description: The construction of the Iron pillar of Delhi in Mathura by the Gupta Empire shows the development of rust-resistant ferrous metallurgy in Ancient India, although original texts do not survive to detail the specific processes invented in this period.

name: horse collar
description: th century: The horse collar as a fully developed collar harness is developed in Northern and Southern dynasties China during the 5th century AD. The earliest depiction of it is a Dunhuang cave mural from the Chinese Northern Wei dynasty, the painting dated to 477–499.

name: Pointed arch bridge
description: th century – 6th century: Pointed arch bridge (Karamagara Bridge) in Cappadocia, Eastern Roman Empire

name: Pendentive
description: Pendentive dome (Hagia Sophia) in Constantinople, Eastern Roman Empire

name: Sulfur matches
description: Sulfur matches exist in China

name: Toilet paper
description: Toilet paper in Sui dynasty China, first mentioned by the official Yan Zhitui (531–591), with full evidence of continual use in subsequent dynasties.

name: Toothbrush
description: Toothbrush in China during the Tang dynasty

name: Greek fire
description: Greek fire in Constantinople, Byzantine Empire: Greek fire, an incendiary weapon likely based on petroleum or naphtha, is invented by Kallinikos, a Lebanese Greek refugee from Baalbek, as described by Theophanes. However, the historicity and exact chronology of this account is dubious, and it could be that Kallinikos merely introduced an improved version of an established weapon.

name: Banknote
location: China during the Tang and Song dynasties
description: th century: Banknote in Tang dynasty China: The banknote is first developed in China during the Tang and Song dynasties, starting in the 7th century. Its roots are in merchant receipts of deposit during the Tang dynasty (618–907), as merchants and wholesalers desire to avoid the heavy bulk of copper coinage in large commercial transactions.

name: Porcelain
description: th century: Porcelain in Tang dynasty China: True porcelain is manufactured in northern China from roughly the beginning of the Tang dynasty in the 7th century, while true porcelain was not manufactured in southern China until about 300 years later, during the early 10th century.

name: Gunpowder
description: th century: Gunpowder in Tang dynasty China: Gunpowder is, according to prevailing academic consensus, discovered in the 9th century by Chinese alchemists searching for an elixir of immortality. Evidence of gunpowder's first use in China comes from the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period (618–907). The earliest known recorded recipes for gunpowder are written by Zeng Gongliang, Ding Du, and Yang Weide in the Wujing Zongyao, a military manuscript compiled in 1044 during the Song dynasty (960–1...

name: Playing card
description: th century: Playing card in Tang dynasty China

name: Fire lance
description: th century: Fire lance in Song dynasty China, developed in the 10th century with a tube of first bamboo and later on metal that shot a weak gunpowder blast of flame and shrapnel, its earliest depiction is a painting found at Dunhuang. Fire lance is the earliest firearm in the world and one of the earliest gunpowder weapons.

name: Fireworks
description: th century: Fireworks in Song dynasty China: Fireworks first appear in China during the Song dynasty (960–1279), in the early age of gunpowder. Fireworks could be purchased from market vendors; these were made of sticks of bamboo packed with gunpowder.

name: Fountain pen
description: Fountain pen: invented at the request of al-Mu'izz li-Din Allah in Arab Egypt.

name: Bessemer process
description: th century: Early versions of the Bessemer process are developed in China.

name: Endless power-transmitting chain drive
description: th century: Endless power-transmitting chain drive by Su Song for the development an astronomical clock (the Cosmic Engine)

name: Calico
description: th century: Calico was developed in Calicut, India.

name: Movable type
description: Movable type in Song dynasty China: The first record of a movable type system is in the Dream Pool Essays, which attributes the invention of the movable type to Bi Sheng.

name: Rocket
description: th century: Rocket for military and recreational uses date back to at least 13th-century China.

name: mechanical escapement
description: th century: The earliest form of mechanical escapement, the verge escapement in Europe.

name: Buttons
description: th century: Buttons (combined with buttonholes) as a functional fastening for closing clothes appear first in Germany.

name: Explosive bomb
description: th century: Explosive bomb in Jin dynasty Manchuria: Explosive bombs are used in 1221 by the Jin dynasty against a Song dynasty city. The first accounts of bombs made of cast iron shells packed with explosive gunpowder are documented in the 13th century in China and are called "thunder-crash bombs", coined during a Jin dynasty naval battle in 1231.

name: Hand cannon
description: th century: Hand cannon in Yuan dynasty China: The earliest hand cannon dates to the 13th century based on archaeological evidence from a Heilongjiang excavation. There is also written evidence in the Yuanshi (1370) on Li Tang, an ethnic Jurchen commander under the Yuan dynasty who in 1288 suppresses the rebellion of the Christian prince Nayan with his "gun-soldiers" or chongzu, this being the earliest known event where this phrase is used.

name: snow goggles
description: th century: Earliest documented snow goggles, a type of sunglasses, made of flattened walrus or caribou ivory are used by the Inuit peoples in the arctic regions of North America. In China, the first sunglasses consisting of flat panes of smoky quartz are documented.

name: Double-entry bookkeeping
description: th century: Double-entry bookkeeping in Italy.

name: Worm gear cotton gin
description: th century - 14th century: Worm gear cotton gin in India.

name: Land mine
description: Land mine in Song dynasty China: Textual evidence suggests that the first use of a land mine in history is by a Song dynasty brigadier general known as Lou Qianxia, who uses an 'enormous bomb' (huo pao) to kill Mongol soldiers invading Guangxi in 1277.

name: Eyeglasses
description: Eyeglasses in Italy

name: Canvas
description: th century: Painting Canvas was first used in Italy.

name: Jacob's staff
description: th century: Jacob's staff described by Levi ben Gerson

name: Naval mine
description: th century: Naval mine in Ming dynasty China: Mentioned in the Huolongjing military manuscript written by Jiao Yu (fl. 14th to early 15th century) and Liu Bowen (1311–1375), describing naval mines used at sea or on rivers and lakes, made of wrought iron and enclosed in an ox bladder. A later model is documented in Song Yingxing's encyclopedia written in 1637.

name: Bidriware
description: th century: Bidriware in the Bahmani Sultanate in India.

name: handgun
description: first use of a handgun

name: Mainspring
description: th century: Mainspring in Europe

name: Brace
description: s: Brace in Flanders, Holy Roman Empire

name: Printing press
description: Printing press in Mainz, Germany: The printing press is invented in the Holy Roman Empire by Johannes Gutenberg before 1440, based on existing screw presses. The first confirmed record of a press appeared in a 1439 lawsuit against Gutenberg.

name: Mariner's astrolabe
description: s: Mariner's astrolabe in Portuguese circumnavigation of Africa

name: Chintz
description: th century: Chintz or printed clothing in Golconda, India

name: Hookah
description: th century: Hookah by Irfan Shaikh, at the court of the Mughal emperor Akbar I

name: Rifling
description: Rifling is first used in firearms, after being invented in 1498

name: Floating dry dock
description: Floating dry dock in Venice, Venetian Republic

name: Mercator Projection
description: Mercator Projection map created by Gerardus Mercator

name: Stocking frame
description: Stocking frame: Invented by William Lee.

name: Backstaff
description: Backstaff: Invented by Captain John Davis

name: Newspaper
description: Newspaper (Relation): Johann Carolus in Strassburg (see also List of the oldest newspapers)

name: Telescope
description: Telescope: Patent applied for by Hans Lippershey. Actual inventor unknown since it seemed to already be a common item being offered by the spectacle makers in the Netherlands with Jacob Metius also applying for patent and the son of Zacharias Janssen making a claim 47 years later that his father invented it.

name: Compound microscopes
description: Compound microscopes, which combine an objective lens with an eyepiece to view a real image, first appear in Europe. Apparently derived from the telescope, actual inventor unknown, variously attributed to Zacharias Janssen (his son claiming it was invented in 1590), Cornelis Drebbel, and Galileo Galilei.

name: Slide rule
description: Slide rule: invented by William Oughtred

name: flintlock
description: first use of the flintlock

name: Mechanical calculator
description: Mechanical calculator. The Pascaline is built by Blaise Pascal.

name: Barometer
description: Barometer: invented by Evangelista Torricelli, or possibly up to three years earlier by Gasparo Berti.

name: Vacuum pump
description: Vacuum pump: Invented by Otto von Guericke.

name: Pendulum clock
description: Pendulum clock: Invented by Christiaan Huygens. It was first conceptualized in 1637 by Galileo Galilei but he was unable to create a working model.

name: reflecting telescope
description: First functional reflecting telescope constructed by Isaac Newton.

name: Pressure-cooker
description: Pressure-cooker: Invented by Denis Papin.

name: Christiaan Huygens
description: Christiaan Huygens provides the first known description of a piston engine.

name: Thomas Savery
description: Thomas Savery develops a steam-powered water pump: for draining mines

name: Bartolomeo Cristofori
description: Bartolomeo Cristofori crafts the first piano, which became a leading instrument of Western art music

name: Thomas Newcomen
description: Thomas Newcomen builds the first commercial steam engine to pump water out of mines.

name: Lewis Paul
description: Lewis Paul and John Wyatt invent the first mechanized cotton spinning machine, helping to establish the British textile industry

name: Musschenbroek
description: Musschenbroek and Kleist independently develop the Leyden jar, an early form of capacitor.

name: John Roebuck
description: John Roebuck invents the lead chamber process, mass producing sulfuric acid for manufacturing

name: William Cullen
description: William Cullen invents the first artificial refrigeration machine

name: James Hargreaves
description: James Hargreaves invents the spinning jenny, revolutionizing textile production during the Industrial Revolution

name: Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot
description: Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot invents the first steam-powered vehicle capable of carrying passengers, an early car

name: John Wilkinson
description: John Wilkinson invents his boring machine, considered by some to be the first machine tool

name: Jesse Ramsden
description: Jesse Ramsden invents the modern screw-cutting lathe

name: John Wilkinson
description: John Wilkinson invents a mechanical air compressor that would become the prototype for all later mechanical compressors

name: Hyder Ali
description: Hyder Ali of Mysore, India develops the first metal-cylinder rockets.

name: Claude de Jouffroy
description: Claude de Jouffroy builds the first steamboat

name: Joseph-Ralf
description: Joseph-Ralf and Jacques-Étienne Montgolfier build the first manned hot air balloon

name: Louis-Sébastien Lenormand
description: Louis-Sébastien Lenormand invents and uses the first modern parachute

name: Martinus van Marum
description: Martinus van Marum is the first to use the electrolysis technique

name: Andrew Meikle
description: Andrew Meikle invents the threshing machine

name: Edmund Cartwright
description: Edmund Cartwright invents the power loom

name: Claude Chappe
description: Claude Chappe invents the semaphore telegraph

name: Eli Whitney
description: Eli Whitney invents the modern cotton gin

name: Joseph Bramah
description: Joseph Bramah invents the hydraulic press

name: Alois Senefelder
description: Alois Senefelder invents the lithography printing technique.

name: vaccine
description: Edward Jenner invented the vaccine and inoculates an individual for smallpox

name: paper machine
description: The first paper machine is invented by Louis-Nicolas Robert

name: Alessandro Volta
description: Alessandro Volta invents the voltaic pile, an early form of battery in Italy, based on previous works by Luigi Galvani.

name: Humphry Davy
description: Humphry Davy invents the arc lamp (exact date unclear; not practical as a light source until the invention of efficient electric generators).

name: Friedrich Sertürner
description: Friedrich Sertürner discovers morphine as the first active alkaloid extracted from the opium poppy plant.

name: Joseph Marie Jacquard
description: Joseph Marie Jacquard develops his automated Jacquard loom.

name: Richard Trevithick
description: Richard Trevithick invents the steam locomotive.

name: Hanaoka Seishū
description: Hanaoka Seishū creates tsūsensan, the first modern general anesthetic.

name: Nicéphore Niépce
description: Nicéphore Niépce invents an early internal combustion engine capable of doing useful work.

name: François Isaac de Rivaz
description: François Isaac de Rivaz designs the first automobile powered by an internal combustion engine fuelled by hydrogen.

name: Robert Fulton
description: Robert Fulton expands water transportation and trade with the workable steamboat.

name: Nicolas Appert
description: Nicolas Appert invents the canning process for food.

name: Abraham-Louis Breguet
description: Abraham-Louis Breguet creates the first wristwatch.

name: Friedrich Koenig
description: Friedrich Koenig invents the first powered printing press, which was also the first to use a cylinder.

name: William Reid Clanny
description: William Reid Clanny pioneered the invention of the safety lamp which he improved in later years. Safety lamps based on Clanny's improved design were used until the adoption of electric lamps.

name: James Fox
description: James Fox invents the modern planing machine, though Matthew Murray of Leeds and Richard Roberts of Manchester have also been credited at times with its invention.

name: René Laennec
description: René Laennec invents the first Stethoscope.

name: Francis Ronalds
description: Francis Ronalds builds the first working electric telegraph using electrostatic means.

name: Robert Stirling
description: Robert Stirling invents the Stirling engine.

name: Karl von Drais
description: Baron Karl von Drais invents the dandy horse, an early velocipede and precursor to the modern bicycle.

name: Marc Isambard Brunel
description: Marc Isambard Brunel invents the tunnelling shield.

name: Thomas Blanchard
description: Thomas Blanchard invents the pattern-tracing lathe (actually more like a shaper). The lathe can copy symmetrical shapes and is used for making gun stocks, and later, ax handles.

name: Nicéphore Niépce
description: Nicéphore Niépce invents Heliography, the first photographic process.

name: Charles Babbage
description: Charles Babbage, considered the "father of the computer", begins building the first programmable mechanical computer.

name: Johann Wolfgang Döbereiner
description: Johann Wolfgang Döbereiner invents the first lighter.

name: Johann Nikolaus von Dreyse
description: Johann Nikolaus von Dreyse invents the bolt-action rifle.

name: William Sturgeon
description: William Sturgeon invents the electromagnet.

name: John Walker
description: John Walker invents the friction match.

name: gas stove
description: James Sharp invents and goes on to manufacture the first practical gas stove.

name: James Beaumont Neilson
description: James Beaumont Neilson develops the hot blast process.

name: Patrick Bell
description: Patrick Bell invents the reaping machine.

name: Ányos Jedlik
description: Hungarian physicist Ányos Jedlik invents the first commutated rotary electromechanical machine with electromagnets.

name: Louis Braille
description: Louis Braille invents the Braille reading system for the blind.

name: air compressor
description: William Mann invents the compound air compressor.

name: Henry Robinson Palmer
description: Henry Robinson Palmer is awarded a patent for corrugated galvanised iron.

name: Edwin Budding
description: Edwin Budding invents the lawn mower.

name: Michael Faraday
description: Michael Faraday invents a method of electromagnetic induction. It would be independently invented by Joseph Henry the following year. Faraday is credited with inventing the first electric generator called the Faraday disk.

name: Charles Babbage
description: Charles Babbage introduces his "mechanical calculating machine", the first mechanical computer

name: Moritz von Jacobi
description: Moritz von Jacobi invents the first practical electric motor.

name: Joseph Henry
description: Joseph Henry invents the electromechanical relay.

name: Samuel Morse
description: Samuel Morse invents Morse code.

name: Moritz von Jacobi
description: Moritz von Jacobi invents electrotyping.

name: William Otis
description: William Otis invents the steam shovel.

name: James Nasmyth
description: James Nasmyth invents the steam hammer.

name: Edmond Becquerel
description: Edmond Becquerel invents a method for the photovoltaic effect, effectively producing the first solar cell.

name: Charles Goodyear
description: Charles Goodyear invents vulcanized rubber.

name: Louis Daguerre
description: Louis Daguerre invents daguerreotype photography.

name: Kirkpatrick Macmillan
description: Kirkpatrick Macmillan invents the first bicycle

name: John Herschel
description: John Herschel invents the blueprint.

name: Alexander Bain
description: Alexander Bain devises a printing telegraph.

name: William Robert Grove
description: William Robert Grove invents the first fuel cell.

name: John Bennet Lawes
description: John Bennet Lawes invents superphosphate, the first man-made fertilizer.

name: Friedrich Gottlob Keller
description: Friedrich Gottlob Keller and, independently, Charles Fenerty come up with the wood pulp method of paper production.

name: Francis Rynd
description: Francis Rynd invents the hypodermic needle.

name: Horace Wells
description: Horace Wells successfully used nitrous oxide as an anesthesia

name: Isaac Charles Johnson
description: Isaac Charles Johnson invents modern Portland cement.

name: tunnel boring machine
description: Henri-Joseph Maus invents the tunnel boring machine.

name: Elias Howe
description: Elias Howe received a patent for a sewing machine, the model for the Singer Sewing Machine

name: Ascanio Sobrero
description: Ascanio Sobrero invents nitroglycerin, the first explosive made that was stronger than black powder.

name: pneumatic drill
description: Jonathan J. Couch invents the pneumatic drill.

name: Linus Yale Sr.
description: Linus Yale Sr. invents the first modern pin tumbler lock.

name: Walter Hunt
description: Walter Hunt invents the first repeating rifle to use metallic cartridges (of his own design) and a spring-fed magazine.

name: James B. Francis
description: James B. Francis invents the Francis turbine.

name: William Armstrong
description: William Armstrong invents the hydraulic accumulator.

name: George Jennings
description: George Jennings offers the first public flush toilets, accessible for a penny per visit, and in 1852 receives a UK patent for the single piece, free standing, earthenware, trap plumed, flushing, water-closet.

name: Robert Bunsen
description: Robert Bunsen is the first to use a chemical vapor deposition technique.

name: Elisha Otis
description: Elisha Otis invents the safety brake elevator.

name: Henri Giffard
description: Henri Giffard becomes the first person to make a manned, controlled and powered flight using a dirigible.

name: reinforced concrete
description: François Coignet invents reinforced concrete.

name: James Clerk Maxwell
description: James Clerk Maxwell invents the first practical method for color photography, whether chemical or electronic.

name: Henry Bessemer
description: Henry Bessemer patents the Bessemer process for making steel, with improvements made by others over the following years.

name: Alexander Parkes
description: Alexander Parkes invents parkesine, also known as celluloid, the first man-made plastic.

name: James Harrison
description: James Harrison produces the world's first practical ice making machine and refrigerator using the principle of vapour compression in Geelong, Australia.

name: William Henry Perkin
description: William Henry Perkin invents mauveine, the first synthetic dye.

name: Heinrich Geissler
description: Heinrich Geissler invents the Geissler tube.

name: phonautograph
description: The phonautograph, the earliest known device for recording sound, is patented and invented by Frenchman Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville.

name: Gaston Planté
description: Gaston Planté invents the lead acid battery, the first rechargeable battery.

name: Joseph Swan
description: Joseph Swan produces carbon fibers.

name: Richard Jordan Gatling
description: Richard Jordan Gatling invents the Gatling gun, the first multi-barrel rapid-fire gun.

name: Louis Pasteur
description: Louis Pasteur invents the pasteurization process.

name: Carl Wilhelm Siemens
description: Carl Wilhelm Siemens and Pierre-Émile Martin invent the Siemens-Martin process for making steel.

name: Alfred Nobel
description: Alfred Nobel invents dynamite, the first safely manageable explosive stronger than black powder.

name: barbed wire
description: Lucien B. Smith invents barbed wire.

name: Polyvinyl chloride
description: Polyvinyl chloride, more commonly known as vinyl, is synthesized by German chemist Eugen Baumann.

name: stainless steel
description: J. E. T. Woods and J. Clark invent stainless steel. Harry Brearley is the first to commercialize it.

name: Frederick Ransome
description: Frederick Ransome invents the rotary kiln.

name: William Crookes
description: William Crookes, a chemist, invents the Crookes radiometer as the by-product of some chemical research.

name: Zénobe Gramme
description: Zénobe Gramme invents the first commercial electrical generator, the Gramme machine.

name: Gustave Trouvé
description: Gustave Trouvé invents the first metal detector.

name: Ferdinand von Zeppelin
description: Ferdinand von Zeppelin invents the Zeppelin rigid airship.

name: Fyodor Pirotsky
description: Fyodor Pirotsky invents the first electric tram near Saint Petersburg, Russia.

name: Nicolaus August Otto
description: Nicolaus August Otto invents the four-stroke cycle.

name: Alexander Graham Bell
description: Alexander Graham Bell has a patent granted for the telephone. However, other inventors before Bell had worked on the development of the telephone and the invention had several pioneers.

name: Thomas Edison
description: Thomas Edison invents the first working phonograph.

name: Henry Fleuss
description: Henry Fleuss is granted a patent for the first practical rebreather.

name: Lester Allan Pelton
description: Lester Allan Pelton invents the Pelton wheel, a type of water turbine.

name: Joseph Swan
description: Joseph Swan and Thomas Edison both patent a functional incandescent light bulb. Some two dozen inventors had experimented with electric incandescent lighting over the first three-quarters of the 19th century but never came up with a practical design. Swan's, which he had been working on since the 1860s, had a low resistance so was only suited for small installations. Edison designed a high-resistance bulb as part of a large-scale commercial electric lighting utility.

name: Nikolay Benardos
description: Nikolay Benardos presents carbon arc welding, the first practical arc welding method.

name: Hiram Maxim
description: Hiram Maxim invents the recoil-operated Maxim gun, ushering in the age of semi- and fully automatic firearms.

name: Paul Vieille
description: Paul Vieille invents Poudre B, the first smokeless powder for firearms.

name: Charles Parsons
description: Sir Charles Parsons invents the modern steam turbine.

name: Károly Zipernowsky
description: Hungarian engineers Károly Zipernowsky, Ottó Bláthy and Miksa Déri invent the closed core high efficiency transformer and the AC parallel power distribution.

name: John Kemp Starley
description: John Kemp Starley invents the modern safety bicycle.

name: Carl Gassner
description: Carl Gassner invents the zinc–carbon battery, the first dry cell battery, making portable electronics practical.

name: Charles Martin Hall
description: Charles Martin Hall and independently Paul Héroult invent the Hall–Héroult process for economically producing aluminum in 1886.

name: Karl Benz
description: Karl Benz invents the first petrol or gasoline powered auto-mobile (car).

name: Carl Josef Bayer
description: Carl Josef Bayer invents the Bayer process for the production of alumina.

name: James Blyth
description: James Blyth invents the first wind turbine used for generating electricity.

name: John Stewart MacArthur
description: John Stewart MacArthur, working in collaboration with brothers Dr. Robert and Dr. William Forrest, develops the process of gold cyanidation.

name: John J. Loud
description: John J. Loud invents the ballpoint pen.

name: Thomas Edison
description: Thomas Edison and William Kennedy Dickson invent the Kinetoscope.

name: pneumatic tire
description: The first practical pneumatic tire was made by Scotsman John Boyd Dunlop, the patent was from 1847 by Robert William Thomson

name: Frédéric Swarts
description: s: Frédéric Swarts invents the first chlorofluorocarbons to be applied as refrigerant.

name: Robert Gair
description: Robert Gair invents the pre-cut cardboard box.

name: Whitcomb Judson
description: Whitcomb Judson invents the zipper.

name: Léon Bouly
description: Léon Bouly invents the cinematograph.

name: Thomas Ahearn
description: Thomas Ahearn invents the electric oven.

name: John Froelich
description: John Froelich invented the gas-powered tractor

name: Rudolf Diesel
description: Rudolf Diesel invents the diesel engine (although Herbert Akroyd Stuart had experimented with compression ignition before Diesel).

name: William Stewart Halsted
description: William Stewart Halsted, invents the rubber glove for his wife Caroline Hampton as he noticed her hands were affected by the daily surgeries she had performed. The gloves were intended to prevent medical staff from developing dermatitis from surgical chemicals. The first modern disposable glove was created by Ansell Rubber Co. Pty. Ltd. in 1965.

name: Guglielmo Marconi
description: Guglielmo Marconi invents the radio, a system of wireless communication using radio waves.

name: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen
description: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen invented the first radiograph (X-ray).

name: Surgical masks
description: Surgical masks made of cloth were developed in Europe by physicians Jan Mikulicz-Radecki at the University of Breslau and Paul Berger in Paris, as a result of increasing awareness of germ theory and the importance of antiseptic procedures in medicine.

name: Hans von Pechmann
description: Hans von Pechmann synthesizes polyethylene, now the most common plastic in the world.

name: Waldemar Jungner
description: Waldemar Jungner invents the rechargeable nickel-cadmium battery (NiCd) as well as the nickel-iron electric storage battery (NiFe) and the rechargeable alkaline silver-cadmium battery (AgCd)

name: vacuum cleaner
description: The first motorized cleaner using suction, a powered "vacuum cleaner", is patented independently by Hubert Cecil Booth and David T. Kenney.

name: gas turbine
description: The first successful gas turbine is invented by Ægidius Elling.

name: laminated glass
description: Édouard Bénédictus invents laminated glass.

name: Fleming valve
description: The Fleming valve, the first vacuum tube and diode, is invented by John Ambrose Fleming.

name: Leo Baekeland
description: Leo Baekeland invents bakelite, the first plastic made from synthetic components.

name: ramjet
description: The tuyères thermopropulsives after 1945 (Maurice Roy (fr)) known as the statoreacteur a combustion subsonique (the ramjet) – R. Lorin

name: Cellophane
description: Cellophane is invented by Jacques E. Brandenberger.

name: Fritz Haber
description: Fritz Haber invents the Haber process.

name: cloud chamber
description: The cloud chamber, the first particle detector, is invented by Charles Thomson Rees Wilson.

name: Bergius process
description: The Bergius process is developed by Friedrich Bergius.

name: Kaplan turbine
description: The Kaplan turbine is invented by Viktor Kaplan.

name: Harry Brearley
description: Harry Brearley invents a process to create Martensitic stainless steel, initially labelled Rustless Steel, later marketed as Staybrite, and AISI Type 420.

name: tanks
description: The first operational military tanks are designed in Great Britain and France. They are used in battle from 1916 and 1917 respectively. The designers in Great Britain are Walter Wilson and William Tritton and in France, Eugène Brillié. (Although it is known that vehicles incorporating at least some of the features of the tank were designed in a number of countries from 1903 onward, none reached a practical form.)

name: Czochralski process
description: The Czochralski process, widely used for the production of single crystal silicon, is invented by Jan Czochralski.

name: crystal oscillator
description: The crystal oscillator is invented by Alexander M. Nicolson using a crystal of Rochelle Salt although his priority was disputed by Walter Guyton Cady.

name: Fischer–Tropsch process
description: The Fischer–Tropsch process is developed by Franz Fischer and Hans Tropsch at the Kaiser-Wilhelm-Institut für Kohlenforschung.

name: Yagi-Uda Antenna
description: The Yagi-Uda Antenna or simply Yagi Antenna is invented by Shintaro Uda of Tohoku Imperial University, assisted by his colleague Hidetsugu Yagi. The Yagi Antenna was widely used during World War II. After the war they saw extensive development as home television antennas.

name: Robert H. Goddard
description: Robert H. Goddard launches the first liquid fueled rocket.

name: Harry Ferguson
description: Harry Ferguson, patents the Three-point hitch equipment linkage system for tractors.

name: John Logie Baird
description: John Logie Baird demonstrates the world's first live working television system.

name: quartz clock
description: The quartz clock is invented by Warren Marrison and J.W. Horton at Bell Telephone Laboratories.

name: Penicillin
description: Penicillin is first observed to exude antibiotic substances by Nobel laureate Alexander Fleming. Development of medicinal penicillin is attributed to a team of medics and scientists including Howard Walter Florey, Ernst Chain and Norman Heatley.

name: Frank Whittle
description: Frank Whittle formally submitted his ideas for a turbo-jet engine. In October 1929, he developed his ideas further. On 16 January 1930, Whittle submitted his first patent (granted in 1932).

name: Philo Farnsworth
description: Philo Farnsworth demonstrates the first practical electronic television to the press.

name: ball screw
description: The ball screw is invented by Rudolph G. Boehm.

name: Supersonic combusting ramjet
description: The Supersonic combusting ramjet — Frank Whittle.[citation needed]

name: Phase-contrast microscopy
description: The Phase-contrast microscopy is invented by Frits Zernike.

name: electron microscope
description: The electron microscope is invented by Ernst Ruska.

name: FM radio
description: FM radio is patented by inventor Edwin H. Armstrong.

name: Harry C. Jennings Sr. and Herbert Everest
description: Harry C. Jennings Sr. and Herbert Everest, both mechanical engineers, invented the first lightweight, steel, folding, portable wheelchair with their "X-brace" design.

name: Nylon
description: Nylon, the first fully synthetic fiber is produced by Wallace Carothers while working at DuPont.

name: Z1
description: Z1, built by Konrad Zuse, is the first freely programmable computer in the world.

name: Nuclear fission
description: Nuclear fission discovered in experiment by chemists Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann and physicists Lise Meitner and Otto Robert Frisch. The German nuclear energy project was based on this research. The Tube Alloys project and, subsequently, the Manhattan Project and the Soviet atomic bomb project were influenced by this research.

name: Naum Gurvich
description: G. S. Yunyev or Naum Gurvich invented the electric current defibrillator

name: John Vincent Atanasoff
description: John Vincent Atanasoff invented the first electronic digital computer

name: Pu-239 isotope
description: Pu-239 isotope (isotope of plutonium) a form of matter existing with the capacity for use as a destructive element (because the isotope has an exponentially increasing spontaneous fissile decay) within nuclear devices — Glenn Seaborg.

name: John Randall
description: John Randall and Harry Boot would develop the high power, microwave generating, cavity magnetron, later applied to commercial Radar and Microwave oven appliances.

name: Polyester
description: Polyester is invented by John Rex Whinfield and James Dickson.

name: V-2 rocket
description: The V-2 rocket, the world's first long range ballistic missile, developed by engineer Wernher von Braun.

name: Enrico Fermi
description: Enrico Fermi developed the nuclear reactor and created the first controlled nuclear chain reaction

name: Manhattan Project
description: The atomic bomb is developed by the Manhattan Project and swiftly used in August 1945 in the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

name: Percy Spencer
description: Percy Spencer, while employed at Raytheon, would patent a magnetron based microwave oven.

name: Willard Libby
description: Willard Libby began his work on radiocarbon dating. He published his paper in 1946, a second paper in Science in 1947. Libby and James Arnold succeeded with the radiocarbon dating theory after results were published in Science in December 1949.

name: James Martin
description: James Martin invents the ejector seat, inspired by the death of his friend and test pilot Captain Valentine Baker in an aeroplane crash in 1942.

name: Holography
description: Holography is invented by Dennis Gabor.

name: Stanolind Oil and Gas Corporation
description: Floyd Farris and J.B. Clark (Stanolind Oil and Gas Corporation) invents hydraulic fracturing technology.

name: transistor
description: The first transistor, a bipolar point-contact transistor, is invented by John Bardeen and Walter Brattain under the supervision of William Shockley at Bell Labs.

name: atomic clock
description: The first atomic clock is developed at the National Bureau of Standards.

name: Basic oxygen steelmaking
description: Basic oxygen steelmaking is developed by Robert Durrer. The majority of steel manufactured in the world is produced using the basic oxygen furnace; in 2000, it accounted for 60% of global steel output.

name: Bertie the Brain
description: Bertie the Brain, debatably the first video game, is displayed to the public at the Canadian National Exhibition.

name: Tokamak
description: The Toroidal chamber with axial magnetic fields (the Tokamak) is developed by Igor E. Tamm and Andrei D. Sakharov.

name: float glass process
description: The float glass process is developed by Alastair Pilkington.

name: thermonuclear weapon
description: The first thermonuclear weapon is developed.

name: video tape recorder
description: The first video tape recorder, a helical scan recorder, is invented by Norikazu Sawazaki.

name: Calvin Souther Fuller
description: Invention of the solar battery by Bell Telephone scientists, Calvin Souther Fuller, Daryl Chapin and Gerald Pearson capturing the Sun's power. First practical means of collecting energy from the Sun and turning it into a current of electricity.

name: hovercraft
description: The hovercraft is patented by Christopher Cockerell.

name: Jonas Salk
description: Jonas Salk received the license for his inactivated polio vaccine

name: intermodal container
description: The intermodal container is developed by Malcom McLean.

name: hard disk drive
description: The hard disk drive is invented by IBM.

name: Logic Theorist
description: The Logic Theorist computer program, the first "artificial intelligence program", was written and invented by Allen Newell, Herbert A. Simon, and Cliff Shaw.

name: laser
description: The laser and optical amplifier are invented and named by Gordon Gould and Charles Townes. The laser and optical amplifier are foundational to powering the Internet.

name: personal computer
description: The first personal computer used by one person and controlled by a keyboard, the IBM 610, is invented by IBM.

name: satellite
description: The first artificial satellite, Sputnik 1, is launched.

name: integrated circuit
description: – 1959: The integrated circuit is independently invented by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce.

name: MOSFET
description: The MOSFET (MOS transistor) is invented by the Egyptian Mohamed Atalla and the Korean Dawon Kahng at Bell Labs. It is used in almost all modern electronic products. It was smaller, faster, more reliable and cheaper to manufacture than earlier bipolar transistors, leading to a revolution in computers, controls and communication.

name: laser
description: The first functioning laser is invented by Theodore Maiman.

name: robotic exoskeleton
description: First robotic exoskeleton

name: electronic cigarette
description: The first electronic cigarette is created by Herbert A. Gilbert. Hon Lik is often credited with its invention as he developed the modern electronic cigarette and was the first to commercialize it.

name: Shinkansen
description: Shinkansen, the first high-speed rail commercial passenger service.

name: Kevlar
description: Kevlar is invented by Stephanie Kwolek at DuPont.

name: Royal Radar Establishment
description: E. A. Johnson of the Royal Radar Establishment developed the capacitive touch display or touchscreen

name: NPL network
description: The NPL network followed by the ARPANET implement packet switching for data communication, drawing on the concepts and designs of Donald Davies, and Paul Baran. These are considered precursors to the modern Internet.

name: Public-key cryptography
description: s: Public-key cryptography is invented and developed by James H. Ellis, Clifford Cocks, Malcolm J. Williamson, Whitfield Diffie, Martin Hellman, Ralph Merkle, Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, Leonard Adleman, et al.

name: pocket calculator
description: The pocket calculator is invented.

name: microprocessor
description: The first single-chip microprocessor, the Intel 4004, is invented. Its development was led by Federico Faggin, using his silicon-gate MOS technology. This led to the personal computer (PC) revolution.

name: space station
description: The first space station, Salyut 1, is launched.

name: IBM
description: IBM developed and released the world's first floppy disk and disk drive.

name: video game console
description: The first video game console, used primarily for playing video games on a TV, is the Magnavox Odyssey.

name: Herbert Boyer
description: Herbert Boyer and Stanley Cohen developed genetic modification when they successfully modified DNA

name: Optelecom
description: The first fiber optic communication systems were developed by Optelecom.

name: graphical user interface
description: The first commercial graphical user interface is introduced in 1973 on the Xerox Alto. The modern GUI is later popularized by the Xerox Star and Apple Lisa.

name: capacitive touchscreen
description: The first capacitive touchscreen is developed at CERN.

name: Transmission Control Program
description: The Transmission Control Program is proposed by Vinton Cerf and Robert E. Kahn, building on the work of Louis Pouzin and other Internet pioneers, creating the basis for the modern Internet.

name: lithium-ion battery
description: The lithium-ion battery is invented by M. Stanley Whittingham, and further developed in the 1980s and 1990s by John B. Goodenough, Rachid Yazami and Akira Yoshino. It has impacted modern consumer electronics and electric vehicles.

name: Rubik's cube
description: The Rubik's cube is invented by Ernő Rubik which went on to be the best selling puzzle ever.

name: home automation
description: First general purpose home automation network technology, X10, was developed

name: DNA sequencing
description: Dr Walter Gilbert and Frederick Sanger invented a new DNA sequencing method for which they won the Nobel Prize.

name: self-driving car
description: The first self-driving car that did not rely upon rails or wires under the road is designed by the Tsukuba Mechanical Engineering Laboratory.

name: Global Positioning System
description: The Global Positioning System (GPS) enters service. While not the first Satellite navigation system, it is the first to enter widespread civilian use

name: in vitro fertilization
description: Birth of the first child through in vitro fertilization (IVF), based on the research of Patrick Steptoe and Robert Edwards

name: Microvision
description: The first handheld game console with interchangeable game cartridges, the Microvision is released.

name: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone
description: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone (NTT) launched the first cellular network in Japan.

name: CompuServe
description: Public dialup information, messaging and e-commerce services, were pioneered through CompuServe and RadioShack's MicroNET, and the UK's Post Office Telecommunications Prestel services.

name: Flash memory
description: Flash memory (both NOR and NAND types) was invented by Fujio Masuoka while working for Toshiba. It was introduced to the public in 1984.

name: Mark Skolnick
description: Scientists Mark Skolnick, Ron Davis, Ray White, and David Botstein published their findings on a gene mapping tool using Restriction Fragment-length Polymorphisms (RFLP), that would have applications to identify heritable disorders, including some forms of cancer.

name: reusable spacecraft
description: The first reusable spacecraft, the Space Shuttle undergoes test flights ahead of full operation in 1982

name: Kane Kramer
description: Kane Kramer develops the credit card-sized, IXI digital media player.

name: Televerket
description: Televerket, a Swedish state-owned corporation, launched the Nordic Mobile Telephone (NMT) system.

name: Comvik
description: Comvik, a Swedish telecommunications company, launched the first commercial automatic cellular system. However, according to the Swedish Post and Telecom Authority, the company launched an unlicensed automatic system. Comvik didn't receive a license to operate until December 1981, two months after the NMT system was launched.

name: CD-ROM
description: A CD-ROM contains data accessible to, but not writable by, a computer for data storage and music playback. The 1985 Yellow Book standard developed by Sony and Philips adapted the format to hold any form of binary data.

name: satellite television
description: Direct to home satellite television transmission, with the launch of Sky One service.

name: laptop
description: The first laptop computer is launched, the 8/16-bit Epson HX-20.

name: Stereolithography
description: Stereolithography is invented by Chuck Hull.

name: AT&T
description: Ameritech, now known as AT&T, commercialized the Bell System (its cellular network) in Chicago, Ill.

name: cell phone
description: The first commercially available cell phone in the US, the DynaTAC 8000X, is created by Motorola.

name: Chuck Hull
description: Chuck Hull patents the stereolithography (SLA) process, also known as 3D printing

name: DNA profiling
description: DNA profiling is pioneered by Alec Jeffreys.

name: Technophone
description: Technophone, a British mobile phone company, created the first pocket-sized cell phone, the Excell PCT105.

name: Karlheinz Brandenburg
description: Karlheinz Brandenburg would publish the audio compression algorithms that would be standardised as the: MPEG-1, layer 3 (mp3), and later the MPEG-2, layer 7 Advanced Audio Compression (AAC).

name: World Wide Web
description: The World Wide Web is invented by computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee.

name: Archie
description: The first search engine, "Archie", was created by Alan Emtage, Bill Heelan, and Peter J. Deutsch at McGill University

name: solid-state drive
description: The first commercial flash-based solid-state drive is launched by SunDisk.

name: sim card
description: The first sim card is developed by Munich smart-card maker Giesecke & Devrient

name: IBM Simon
description: IBM Simon, the world's first smartphone, is developed by IBM. It had a touchscreen and the first built-in apps for a mobile device.

name: Bluetooth
description: First generation of Bluetooth is developed by Ericsson Mobile. A form of data communication on short distances between electronic devices

name: Tetris
description: A Tetris variant on the Hagenuk MT-2000 device becomes the first mobile game

name: DVD
description: DVD is an optical disc storage format, invented and developed by Philips, Sony, Toshiba, and Panasonic. DVDs offer higher storage capacity than compact discs while having the same dimensions.

name: Ciena Corporation
description: The Ciena Corporation, in partnership with Sprint, deployed the first commercial dense wavelength-division multiplexing system, which created the massive capacity of the Internet.

name: Nokia 9000 Communicator
description: Mobile web was first commercially offered in Finland on the Nokia 9000 Communicator phone, and it was also the first phone with texting

name: Bolt
description: Bolt and Six Degrees (1997) both become the first social media sites.

name: Myriad Genetics
description: Myriad Genetics released the BRACAnalysis, the first commercial genetic test for assessing the risk of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.

name: Google
description: The search engine Google, is launched.

name: capsule endoscopy
description: The first capsule endoscopy was performed, after being invented in the mid-1990s by Gavriel Iddan

name: digital video recorder
description: The first digital video recorder (DVR), the TiVo, is launched

name: NTT DoCoMo
description: NTT DoCoMo launches i-mode, the first integrated Online App store for mobile phones

name: Food and Drug Administration
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first contraceptive patch

name: Android operating system
description: Development of the Android operating system for mobile devices

name: podcast
description: First podcast, invented by Adam Curry and Dave Wine

name: YouTube
description: YouTube, the first popular video-streaming site, was founded by Jawed Karim

name: Amazon
description: Amazon pioneered cloud computing

name: Apple Inc.
description: Apple Inc. released the iPhone

name: Kindle
description: First Kindle e-reader introduced by Amazon

name: video on demand
description: Subscription video on demand first offered by Netflix and Hulu

name: Satoshi Nakamoto
description: Satoshi Nakamoto develops the first blockchain.

name: quantum machine
description: The first quantum machine was created by Aaron D. O'Connell

name: synthetic organism
description: The first synthetic organism, Mycoplasma laboratorium is created by the J. Craig Venter Institute

name: Lidar
description: Solid-state Lidar technology was introduced, replacing mechanical scanning with electronic beam steering

name: Siri
description: Apple released Siri, the first major company's virtual assistant

name: Pepper
description: Introduction of Pepper, the first commercial humanoid robot

name: Amazon Echo
description: Introduction of the Amazon Echo alongside Amazon Alexa, introducing smart home technology to homes

name: CRISPR gene editing
description: Discovery of CRISPR gene editing method

name: OpenAI
description: OpenAI was introduced by Elon Musk and Sam Altman

name: artificial pancreas
description: First commercially available artificial pancreas

name: SpaceX
description: First successful launch of a multi-use rocket by SpaceX

name: IBM
description: IBM launches IBM Q System One, its first integrated quantum computing system for commercial use.

name: 5G
description: 5G broadband cellular network technology introduced

name: MRNA vaccine
description: The first MRNA vaccine to be approved by public health medicines regulators is co-developed by Pfizer and BioNTech for COVID-19, with the potential to treat other diseases and cancer

name: OpenAI
description: OpenAI demonstrated an Artificial Intelligence model called GPT-3. The program was created to generate human-like responses when given prompts.

name: ChatGPT
description: ChatGPT is launched to the public, making it the first mainstream generative AI to be released
